summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 discussing privilege review of materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein. The correspondence involves government personnel coordinating with Epstein's former attorneys and estate representatives to identify privileged attorney-client communications, specifically mentioning private investigator materials and attorney contact lists.

persons.name: Marty Weinberg
persons.context: Identified as one of Epstein's attorneys who likely provided a list of privilege terms to a government contact in July 2019.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Identified as one of Epstein's attorneys who likely provided a list of privilege terms to a government contact.

persons.name: Michael Miller
persons.context: Identified as one of Epstein's attorneys who likely provided a list of privilege terms to a government contact.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Identified as Epstein's attorney from the firm Black Srebnick Kornspan & Stumpf. The email discusses whether communications from a private investigator also named Roy Black might actually be from this attorney.

persons.name: Andrew Tomback
persons.context: Identified as representing the co-executors of Epstein's estate alongside Marc Weinstein.

persons.name: Marc Weinstein
persons.context: Identified as representing the co-executors of Epstein's estate alongside Andrew Tomback.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Identified as one of the co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: His email address was flagged during the privilege review of the seized Epstein database, indicating he represented Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the search warrant and the deceased individual whose estate and former attorneys are the focus of the privilege review.

connections.description: Weinberg is identified as an attorney who represented Epstein, providing privilege terms to the government.
Weingarten is identified as an attorney who represented Epstein, providing privilege terms to the government.
Miller is identified as an attorney who represented Epstein, providing privilege terms to the government.
Roy Black of Black Srebnick Kornspan & Stumpf is identified as an attorney who represented Epstein.
Goldberger's email was found in seized materials, and he is noted as having represented Epstein.
Tomback, along with Marc Weinstein, represents Indyke in his role as co-executor of Epstein's estate.
Weinstein, along with Andrew Tomback, represents Indyke in his role as co-executor of Epstein's estate.

events.title: Privilege Terms Provided by Epstein Attorneys
events.description: Epstein's attorneys (Marty Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and/or Michael Miller) provided a list of privilege terms directly to a government contact.

events.title: Privilege Review of Epstein Seized Materials
events.description: Government personnel conduct a privilege review of a database from Epstein search warrants, coordinating with his former attorneys and estate representatives.

keyFacts: The document reveals a post-Epstein death (2020) government review of seized materials, requiring coordination with his former defense team and estate attorneys to identify privileged communications.
Epstein's defense team included several high-profile attorneys: Marty Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, Michael Miller, Roy Black, and Jack Goldberger.
The estate of Jeffrey Epstein is represented by co-executors, including Darren Indyke, whose attorneys are Andrew Tomback and Marc Weinstein.
The review uncovered communications from private investigators hired by Epstein, raising questions about whether those materials are protected by attorney-client privilege.
The email chain shows direct, non-case-team communication occurred between government contacts and Epstein's attorneys in July 2019 regarding privilege terms.
